ISetHelp.message: $$$ add some real text here $$$
Used to change the weighting for background illumination (ie light that's not from any particular light source). This should normally be between 0 and 1.

To determine whether a point is within the fractal the point is iterated using the fractal formula. If the result is larger than bailout the point is consided to be outside the fractal. Larger values may result in a more accurate view of the fractal.
The x coordinate of the camera location.
The y coordinate of the camera location.
The z coordinate of the camera location.
The x coordinate of the point the camera is focused on.
The y coordinate of the point the camera is focused on.
The z coordinate of the point the camera is focused on.
The x coordinate of a vector that defines the direction the camera considers 'up'.
The y coordinate of a vector that defines the direction the camera considers 'up'.
The z coordinate of a vector that defines the direction the camera considers 'up'.
The distance from the camera to the plane from which rays are cast at the fractal.
The distance from the camera to the plane at which a ray cast from the yon plane terminates.
The width of the view plane (this is in world coordinates: not pixels).
The height of the view plane (this is in world coordinates: not pixels).
The x coordinate of a constant value used by some of the fractal formulas.
The y coordinate of a constant value used by some of the fractal formulas.
The z coordinate of a constant value used by some of the fractal formulas.
The w coordinate of a constant value used by some of the fractal formulas.
Random values will be between min random and max random.
Random values will be between min random and max random.
Used to change the weighting for light sources. This should normally be between 0 and 1.
The x coordinate of a constant value used by some of the fractal formulas.
The y coordinate of a constant value used by some of the fractal formulas.
The z coordinate of a constant value used by some of the fractal formulas.
The w coordinate of a constant value used by some of the fractal formulas.
Random values will be between min random and max random.
Random values will be between min random and max random.
To determine whether a point is within the fractal the point is iterated using the fractal formula. If the formula is iterated max dwell times the point is considered to be inside the fractal.
The x coordinate of the light location.
The y coordinate of the light location.
The z coordinate of the light location.
The light's intensity. This will usually be betwen 0 and 1, but can be greater than 1 if you want to overdrive the light or less than 0 for shadow lights.
Click this to turn the light on.

ISetCheckedHelp.message: Click this to turn the light off.

IColorSwatch.prompt: Pick a color for the light:

ISetHelp.message: Click this to select a new color for the light.
Click this to stop the light's intensity from decreasing with distance from the light.
Click this to make the light's intensity decrease linearly with distance.
Click this to make the light's intensity decrease with the square of the distance.
The default width (in pixels) of new fractal windows..
The default height (in pixels) of new fractal windows..
Fractals will be rendered using 16-bit color. This will use 25% less memory than millions of colors, but the images may not look quite as nice.
Fractals will be rendered using 32-bit color. This uses more memory but produces slightly better images.
If you select this HyperMandella will create a new untitled fractal when it starts up.
If you select this HyperMandella will bring up the open dialog when it starts up.
If you select this HyperMandella won't do anything special when it starts up.
The number of colors in each randomized palette.
The number of random colors chosen for each palette. (The other colors are generated by interpolating between two random colors).
Logarithmic weighting of the saturation component of the colors. Larger numbers result in colors nearer white.
Logarithmic weighting of the value component of the colors. Larger numbers result in brighter colors.
The number of horizontal pixels in the fractal.
The number of vertical pixels in the fractal.
The number of discrete steps to take when shooting a ray from the camera to the yon plane.
Click this to keep the fractal's aspect ratio constant.
Click this to keep the number of pixels in the fractal constant.
Click this if you want to make changes to one component without affecting the other component.
Used to change the weighting for the specular highlighting. This should normally be between 0 and 1.
Used to change the size of specular highlightes. Larger numbers reduce the size of the highlighted region.
The value of the fourth coordinate used when computing the fractals (this defines a 3D slice through the four dimensional space).
Random values will be between min random and max random.
Random values will be between min random and max random.
